summary: Simon comments more on Early Access plans.
mainText: Simon believes the game will eventually be good enough that it won't need a disclaimer about the history, but he'd include a disclaimer and a roadmap explanation early on. The Lore/Story wouldn't be included in early releases, and it'd be implemented into adventure mode using the dungeon/quest systems - but no promises.

3: No Lore/Story in-game in early access.

summary: Simon discusses the 2016 trailer.
mainText: According to Simon, some features in the trailer were broken/in early development, but most of it was easily fixable. Everything was filmed using in-game cinematic tools, which allowed placement of cameras and usage of events (like the dragon shot at the end). Simon says cinematic tools were invested in because the team understands how important YouTube is to a game's success. Some shots in the trailer were scripted, due to lack of players, and NPCs were used to make it feel more alive - specifically the minigames and end shot in the trailer. Simon notes three specific features: #1 being the mounts & hot air balloon, which used a band-aid solution, but could be fixed in a couple of weeks and might have been done already, #2 being minecarts with jumping not being implemented, and #3 being the World Map which was using a better UI than what was in-game at the time. After the trailer's release, the features shown were top priority to be completed. Simon clarifies that the trailer was faithful to the game and vision in 2018, and explains that the cinema tools allowed users to record their actions and play it back.

summary: Simon discusses Survival/Adventure mode, alterverses.
mainText: In a series of tweets, Simon talks about how Survival mode probably isn't balanced at the moment and might lack features, but it might be okay because it creates a blank canvas with a lot of content, with the game slowly coming together over rapid updates. Pivoting to alterverses, Simon reveals he discussed with a former Hytale designer about how Hytale's alterverses could work - potentially being added after the base game is good, and releasing with new story chapters, dungeons, blocks, weapons, and armor tiers, almost like how World of Warcraft handles expansions.

summary: Simon says Hytale is a 10yr+ project
mainText: When asked for his view of what Hytale should be, a game, a platform, or something in the middle, Simon says Hytale is a 10+ years project, and he'd properly communicate his vision from day one.

summary: Simon discusses Hytale's popularity, minigames, and Day 1 possibilities.
mainText: When asked about potentially returning to Hytale's popularity in '19, Simon says that popularity doesn't matter much as long as the funding to continue updates is still there, as a good game attracts players naturally - though he mentions a hypothetical free minigame-only version could be used to attract players. Continuing that sentiment, Simon states he doesn't care about how much polished content is already in the game, as the community would help polish it over the years. Turning to servers, Simon reveals that he believes most Hypixel classic minigames were cancelled in Hytale's new direction, but with Day 1 player-hosted servers and an eventual Servers Tab, minigames would be created by the community - potentially aided by official prototypes/maps. The average player could aid the game by reporting bugs, requesting features, creating content, and generally participating in the community.

summary: Simon comments on feedback/requests for building tools.
mainText: Responding to Hawkon's Hytale building tools video, Simon confirms that Legacy Hytale already has hotbar-swapping in Creative mode, and he agrees with most of the suggestions about the menus. Simon also discusses the suggested Ghost Mode feature, saying no-clip options already exist - saying he has experienced the frustration of no-clip mode still triggering redstone in Minecraft. Speaking on the video as a whole, Simon says it's the type of video that the developers would watch to understand the needs of creatives and implement them.

summary: Simon discusses Hytale having limited content early, eventually coming to Steam.
mainText: Responding to a doubtful/cynical Twitter user on July 29th, Simon points out that Minecraft and Roblox both had limited content initially, and neither came to Steam - he says that he is unique when compared to other indie studios because he's always had positive cash flow since Day 1 with the Hypixel server, and can fund production over several years. The following day, Simon says Hytale will eventually come to Steam, pointing out that the 30% revenue share w/ Steam would also save 30% in expenses and provide 30% more players, and while he cares about the game's condition, he wants to release quickly. By staying off Steam initially, Hytale avoids negative reviews from people who don't understand the circumstances/context.

summary: Simon discusses Hytale having a soul, it being his final work.
mainText: When asked, Simon says Hytale would be his final work, and he'd work on it for years - viewing it as a legacy project and a passion project that he can have his kids play in the future. It's not a cash grab, like The Day Before, as it has a soul and would continue to get support for a long time.

summary: Simon explains selling Hytale, post-sale role.
mainText: Simon explains that he sold Hytale because he didn't have the money to finish it, and new leadership wanted to go a different direction. Selling Hytale gave the team way more funding, and he got money to make investments that have put him in the position he's in today to buy Hytale back. Interestingly enough, Simon says he was supposed to be an advisor after the sale, but he wasn't contacted and he was under the impression they were doing fine.

summary: Simon discusses Hytale Creator Program, release/communication thoughts.
mainText: Simon states that he'd probably make a tweet and a blogpost to announce Hytale Saved, and the game would likely come out so quickly that there'd be no early access for creators (though he sees importance of a Creator Program) and potentially no real blogposts. Old blogposts would be updated to note outdated info, and any new blogposts would quickly transition to patch notes!

1: How Hytale Saved will be announced

summary: Simon discusses Story/Adventure mode content.
mainText: While Simon admits he doesn't know much about the story/lore and has no final answer on if Adventure mode and Survival mode would be separate, he believes there's a way for story content to be added to pre-existing worlds -- potentially in chapters slowly releasing over time, as he isn't sure if a single story quest was done.

summary: Simon discusses Hytale features + living world.
mainText: According to Simon, Hytale has an instanced dungeon system in Legacy Engine, which would enable insane amounts of content, just like the Proximity VC and the Cinema system (which was apparently removed in new engine) would. When asked about social systems, Simon affirms support for friends system (potentially on Day 1) and other social systems. When asked about the world, Simon says having a 'living world' is critical, with wind sounds/visuals and NPCs changing behavior (partially) based on time/weather. Wanting to avoid formal tutorials, Simon expresses love for charm/mechanics that create player stories, describing a scenario where taking care of a wounded animal could teach the basics of survival - likely post-launch.

summary: Simon discusses Legacy Engine details + launcher info.
mainText: In a day full of tweets, Simon states that Hytale's legacy engine (C# client, Java backend) has options for cross-play, which would need to be looked into, and plugins/modding 'probably' work both like Minecraft's Java plugins + the scripting, which was shown in the original trailer. Java is used for the backend because it aids in speed of development, enables developers to be trained more easily, and already has a massive server/modding community. Additionally, Simon says he'd try to make parts of the game shared source or open source, with a bounty system for bugs/features. When asked about a launcher, Simon explains that the game would be updated very frequently, making an independent launcher ideal initially - though Simon believes a Steam release would be best down the line (following in Path of Exile's footsteps), with a goal being Hytale on the Steam Deck (with Windows/Mac support confirmed + Linux potentially being possible). Of course, Custom Input Support would also be ideal.

summary: Simon discusses the financials, community events.
mainText: Responding to a user, Simon clarifies that his previously mentioned figure of $25M USD would be put towards development, with $1M-$2M likely being burnt before release. There were no plans on monetization of Hytale due to many offers, and Simon states that the price of the game will depend on math being done later. Additionally, Simon says there won't be events like 'Hycon' or even offices before the game is released and feels good, but it's good to know he'd always be invited.

summary: Simon discusses various features in Hytale.
mainText: Simon discussed with an ex-Hytale dev, who stated that exploration was insanely good, with tons of prefabs and a crazy underground to explore, and Simon says it was amazing in '19 and is apparently much better now - with an incomparable amount of handcrafted work. In addition to this, Simon says he'd need to look into Zone 4 returning and the possibility of Peer-2-Peer Co-Op, and says it'd make sense to let players keep their world and access new content later.

summary: Simon discusses potential early access tiers, E.A. day one.
mainText: Simon floats the idea of having 2/3 tiers of Early Access support - T1 being lower price for people who want to try the game, T2 having cosmetics for supporting, and T3 having multiple access keys + extra cosmetics. Alongside a creative mode, Early Access Day One would likely have a very barebones survival mode (with great exploration), with Adventure (Story) Mode coming later down the line when there is more content and a more complete survival gameplay loop. Players would be able to host their own servers, but no official server/minigames on day one.

summary: Simon updates on Proximity Chat, discusses community created experiences.
mainText: After discussing with a ex-Hytale dev, Simon reports that it's possible to add proximity voice chat back to the game, and personally says he will personally make sure it happens because of the potential fun and chaos it could add, and because (when combined with climbing/vaulting mechanics) it could easily enable a Peak-like minigame -- another reason to get the community involved and able to make custom maps/mods early on.

summary: Simon clarifies his SaveHytale intent.
mainText: Answering various users on Twitter, Simon clarifies that he intends to only buy the Hytale IP - which can be code, art, name, etc. -  NOT the whole business, which he says makes it a simpler transaction that isn't like in the movies. He further clarifies that while negotiation wouldn't last long, the initiation of talks and the drafting of agreements is the real time sink. Simon continues by saying that a large percentage of a company's worth is in the people - which Hytale no longer has - and that because the Legacy Engine is not cross-platform and because the New Engine is far from playable, Hytale isn't a great value to most medium/big studios. These details make his bid the only decent option for Hytale, in his eyes.

summary: Simon discusses proximity chat/other features.
mainText: Simon states that proximity voice chat in Hytale was experimented on in '17-'18, and he was a big believer in the feature, and believes it would open many doors to new gameplay experiences. While he can't commit to split-screen functionality, Simon says that Hytale had lots of great unique features that are now considered common in other games.

summary: Simon explains why Hytale servers were Java-based / original drive for Hytale.
mainText: Simon says that the reason Hytale servers are Java-based is due to the size of the Minecraft server/modding ecosystem, which fostered a very specific hiring pool with lots of dedicated developers. The original drive for Hytale was to build Hypixel's dream platform and a game alongside it, and then to share the tools / platform with others!

summary: Simon explains why he's so communicative about SaveHytale efforts.
mainText: When questioned on if his constant communication leads to rising expectations, Simon explains that the years of silence didn't work for Hytale. By communicating, he says, it helps him see that Hytale is worth fighting for. Simon reiterates that Hytale is 100% dead without his communication and efforts, stating that saving Legacy Hytale makes no business sense. Simon says he believes in Hytale, and attempting to save it is his way of giving back what he was given years ago.

summary: Simon discusses Hytale's fantasy feel, status of new content, and fan feedback.
mainText: Simon emphasizes the importance of great non-sandbox experiences, stating that that is why Hytale has a heavy fantasy feel, with quests. When asked, Simon says the new combat system looks much better than when he was at Hytale, and says everything good would stay in. Simon finishes the day by saying he'd like to do a blogpost/Q&A in the future to gather fan opinions and feedback on initial plans + communicate new direction.

summary: Simon discusses potential first steps.
mainText: Simon says the first steps would be to evaluate the project, clean it up, and then achieve a basic (if limited) game loop before creating a roadmap. He clarifies that a lot of content would be cut early on, just to get the game out and start generating funds, saying a creative mode could be released at least, allowing the community to get involved while finishing other aspects of the game.

summary: Simon discusses releasing an unfinished project.
mainText: Simon talks about the courage required to release an unfinished project, and that searching for perfection just leads to expectations becoming bigger and bigger as time passes and promises are made. When you get to the point of rewriting every system (and even things like music), Simon says, you've lost the plot. Simon believes the AI Combat system, which had previously been showcased, likely had to be rewritten for the new (Forge) engine.

summary: Simon decides to Save Hytale.
mainText: Simon announces his decision to try and save Hytale, explaining that it'd take less money to get a Very Early Access version w/ temporarily removed features out to the community. His plan is to Just Launch, and get the community involved ASAP and use Shared Source and Open Source to help production. He cautions fans to keep their expectations low, as the chances are next to impossible, but he isn't afraid to release in a temporarily bad state.

summary: Simon's discusses potential of 'saving' Hytale.
mainText: When asked if he thought it'd be worth looking into saving Hytale, Simon says he hasn't seen the game since '19, and it would be difficult financially - likely requiring parts of the game/tools to be open source.

summary: Simon considers saving Hytale, discusses what it would take.
mainText: Simon says he'd be willing to put $25M by himself to finish Hytale - saying it would be raw passion, high pressure, high risk, and would require a reduced scope with the legacy engine, be PC only, and require unfinished features to be cut to get the game into the hands of players ASAP. He admits he is considering trying to save Hytale.

summary: Simon's first statement on Hytale, post-cancellation.
mainText: During Simon's time working on Hytale ('16-'19), Hytale was <= 2 years from PC release. Simon states that the team was locked in and momentum was insane, with the game shaping up fast towards release. The attention and pressure that the Riot Games label + the trailer put pressure on the team, and Simon felt he couldn't live up to the new expectations - and thus left the team. Simon says Riot was good to him when he left, and gave freedom to the team, and he even turned down 'way more' money from a different company at the last moment because he truly believed Riot Games gave the team/game the best chance of success.

summary: Simon discusses the unique feeling of Hytale.
mainText: Simon says the music/art/sounds of Hytale created an immersive, beautiful world - even 5+ years ago. He describes it as a 'unique artistic experience' that he hadn't experienced before in games in the same genre. He says Riot didn't offer to sell Hytale back to him, as they were likely looking for someone who could support the expenses of the team for years to come.
